item.title: Mortgage Rate Locks in Florida: When to Lock, How Long, and What Happens If Rates Drop
item.description:
You get a rate quote. Should you lock immediately or wait? If you lock and rates drop, are you stuck? If you don’t lock and rates spike, did you blow it? Here’s how rate locks actually work in Florida—and how to time them without gambling.

What a Rate Lock Actually Is

A rate lock is a written agreement that the lender will honor a specific interest rate for a set period (usually 30–60 days) regardless of market changes.

item.title: Rate Lock Strategies for Construction: How I Locked at 6.75% and Saved $28,000
item.description:
When I signed my builder contract in March 2023, interest rates were sitting at 6.75% for construction-to-permanent loans.

My lender offered me two options:

Option 1: Lock your rate today at 6.75% for 12 months (with a float-down option if rates drop)
Option 2: Float your rate and lock later when your home is closer to completion

I had a decision to make: Lock now and hope rates don’t drop? Or float and risk rates going up?
